One of the most common reasons that people cut down on showering is 
actually for skin-health reasons, not laziness. The natural body oils that 
lubricate and protect the skin get washed away by warm (and especially hot) 
showers paired with soaps that strip the skin. Without those oils, the skin 
is more vulnerable to bacteria and viruses, and can also look and feel dry 
and uncomfortable.﻿

+SnipeYouFromMars This statement "they are just theories" is a fallacy of

theory is not an assumption or conjecture -- which is a popular definition 
that has nothing to do with the use of the word "theory" as used in the 
context of science, e.g. "the theory of evolution," which is a SET of 
principles -- not merely an opinion that evolution happens.

As previously stated, panthera hybrids are often fertile and have even been 
cross-bred with other panthera hybrids. Ursus hybrids have bred to create 
3/4 grizzly, 1/4 polar bears. Western and Eastern Grey Kangaroo hybrids 
produce fertile females. In wolf/dog hybrids there is no decrease in 
fertility and coyote or jackal hybrids with dogs only show decreased 
fertility after several generations of interbreeding. Sheep/goat hybrids 
are known to have fertile offspring, both male and female. Beefalos 
(cattle/bison hybrids) are known to be fertile, there's even a breed 
association that defines a beefalo as 3/8 (37.5%) bison. A Dzo is a 
yak/cattle cross - the female hybrids are fertile. Yak/Bison hybrids also 
produce fertile females. European bison (wisent) are similarly 
female-fertile, and in all these bovine species female hybrids bred with 
either of their parent species produce fertile males. Bactrian/Dromedary 
camel crosses are fertile, as are boar/pig crosses. A known example of a 
female wholphin has produced several offspring.
Mustelids (ferrets, weasels, polecates etc.) also produce fertile females.
Humans are fertile, in spite of a significant population carrying 
Neanderthal genes, and it is theorised that for over a million years after 
the human/chimpanzee divergence ancestors of both modern species were still 
interbreeding successfully - meaning we are possibly the most common hybrid 
animal on the planet.

The presenter means well, but he should do a bit more simple research 
before making some of his statements. He is misinforming his audience about 
the specifics of human evolution (and this is something secularists should 
avoid - we shouldn't add to the confusion about evolution - especially 
human evolution). A simple Google or Wikipedia search would have provided 
the correct information. 

Modern humans (Homo sapiens) did NOT evolve from Neanderthals (Homo 
neanderthalensis). Neaderthals were a completely different line of humans 
in the family tree of different human species. We share a very recent 
common ancestor with Neanderthals (so they were essentially our extremely 
close evolutionary cousins). Most likely, our shared ancestor was Homo 
heidelbergensis. Some Homo heidelbergensis left Africa and migrated into 
the Middle East, Asia and Europe and some of them eventually evolved into 
Homo neanderthalensis (Neanderthals), while some of the Homo 
heidelbergensis that stayed in Africa eventually evolved into Homo sapiens 
(our species).

Later on, when some Homo sapiens (our species) eventually left Africa and 
migrated into the Middle East, Europe and Asia, there were still remnant 
populations of Homo neanderthalensis living in those regions.....and there 
were a few instances of interspecies hybridization before all of the 
Neanderthals eventually went extinct. So, today all Homo sapiens (our 
species) whose ancestors were from regions outside of sub-Saharan Africa 
have between 1% and 4% of their genes coming from Neanderthal ancestors 
(products of those few ancient hybridization events).﻿

Fun fact: gravity is also a scientific theory. Are you going to try and 
convince me that gravity is not "fact" because it is a "theory"? What most 
of society does not realize is that the word theory in the scientific 
community has a completely different meaning than it does in average 
society. Here are the exact definitions:

Theory: a supposition or a system of ideas intended to explain something, 
especially one based on general principles independent of the thing to be 
explained. (*cough* i.e. religion, god *cough*)

Scientific Theory: A scientific theory is a well-substantiated explanation 
of some aspect of the natural world that is acquired through the scientific 
method, and repeatedly confirmed through observation and experimentation. 

Note the phrases "well-substantiated explanation" and "repeatedly 
confirmed" in the definition of scientific theory. So yes, evolution is a 
scientific theory, along with hubble's laws, newton's laws, planetary 
motion, and oh yeah, gravity. Funny, no one disputes any of those. Fact is, 
evolution IS the obvious truth. Do the research. The answers are all there.

Did you do your reseach dummy?


The outermost layer of your skin's surface (called the stratum corneum or 
horny layer) is a barrier made of hardened, dead skin cells. These skin 
cells offer protection for the underlying layers of living, healthy cells. 
The horny layer is more than just dead skin cells; it's held together by 
lipids, which are fatty compounds that actually help maintain moisture in 
your skin.
Anytime you take a shower -- especially a hot one -- with soap and a 
scrubbing device like a washcloth or a loofah, you're undermining the 
integrity of your skin's horny layer. The soap and the hot water dissolve 
the lipids in the skin and scrubbing only hastens the process. The more 
showers you take, the more frequently this damage takes place and the less 
time your skin has to repair itself through natural oil production. What's 
more, the horny layer of your skin can be sloughed off by scrubbing, 
exposing the delicate skin cells beneath. The result of showering too 
frequently is generally dry, irritated and cracked skin.﻿
